Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: Qualitative Relational Navigation using Minimal Sensing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of this research is to develop a navigation methodology for robots using relational geometric models that are constructed and evaluated using minimal sensing. The use of qualitative states is both intuitive to human perception, and amenable to long-term operations in robotics because of the inherent scalability and simplicity in sensing. The technical approach consists of four tasks. The first task is to create a mathematical representation that supports relational sensing/maps/navigation. The second task is to extend the representation and methods to include uncertainties, which allows the work to be of practical significance. The third task is to develop a hypothesis based navigation methodology that naturally enables planning over minimal, uncertain relational maps and sensor data. Finally, the theory will be validated using an increasingly complex set of experimental validation tests. This research enables robust navigation of robots in applications such as autonomous driving and personal robotics, as well as applications that have unstructured environments with no GPS access, such as exploration (under water, planetary, caves), disaster relief and search and rescue. The research is particularly well suited to robots that have sensing and computational constraints. In the long term, it is envisioned that the algorithms and software enable life-long learning in robotics because of the ability to scale to long-term operations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, a series of qualitative map representations were developed that have the benefit of capturing key characteristics of an environment, but without specific detail that can create robustness problems when future sensor mistakes occur. The first map uses geometric relationships between landmark triplets in the formulation, thus capturing the relationship between one triplet and another. The second map extended this approach to a general region based on the quality and scale of information within it; for example, an open space is a single region, but a cluttered space would have many small regions. A third type of map extended the work to capture probabalistic qualities of the regions.

Finally, two types of navigation approaches were developed for qualitative maps. The first uses a relative neighborhood graph to generate a sequence of landmark objectives for navigation. A hierarchical approach was then developed for more general qualitative maps, including probabilistic versions. The approaches were validated using JPL Mars yard data, in-lab sensor data, and experimental robot navigation in a woody-urban environment. 

This research will enable robust navigation of robots in applications such as autonomous driving and personal robotics, as well as applications that have unstructured environments with no GPS access, such as exploration (under water, planetary, caves), disaster relief and search and rescue. The research will be particularly well suited to robots that have sensing and computational constraints. It is envisioned that this work could be applicable to other applications, such as human opinion modeling and fusion and probabilsitic decision making. 

Two PhD students completed their PhDs under this project, and three journal papers and two conference papers were published, and two additional journal papers are under review. Undergraduate students and underprepresented students participated in the simulation and experimental validation portions of the project.
